question.title: Why the inherited method output parent's data?
question.body:
Explain please why the output is "Base" ? Isn't getClassName method inherited?

class Base {
    public String className = "Base";

    public String getClassName() {
        return className;
    }
}

class Derived extends Base {
    public String className = "Derived";
}

public class Test {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        System.out.println(new Derived().getClassName());
    }
}

answers.body:
Methods can be overridden. Fields cannot be overridden — only hidden.

class Base {
    public String className = "Base";

    public String getClassName() {
        return className;   // <-- refers to Base.className
    }
}

class Derived extends Base {
    public String className = "Derived";  // <-- hides Base.className
}

Of course the method is inherited. If it wasn't, you code wouldn't compile. That has nothing to do with it. The issue here is that data isn't polymorphic. The method can only see the className that is in scope, and that's the one in the base class. Declaring another one in a derived class doesn't magically change that.

No, it seems you have an incorrect conception of inheritance. The getClassName() method is inherited, so you can call it via an instance of Derived, but the member data that it can see is defined by its scope, which is Base, so it returns Base.className. I've already stated all this. The fact that it is inherited by Derived and that Derived also has a className member doesn't change that. The problem here is not about inheritance, it is that data members are not overridden.
So it seems the word inherited doesn't have the same sense as in real world. It doesn't mean the child class has it. It like the child class has the parent class with all it's stuff in a bag

For a class (yes, you only have one for a given object) to have two attributes with the same name is a programming aberration. To achieve what you want, you must do it like this:


class Base {

    public String className = “Base”;

      // to create “Base” objects 
    public Base() {}

      // to create “Derived” objects... or not
    public Base( String name ) {
        className = name;
    }
    public String getClassName() {
        return className;
    }
}

class Derived extends Base {

    public Derived() {

         // we call the “Base” constructor and pass it the new value for ‘className’
       super( “Derived” );
    }
}

The key point is that the method is inherited, but the data it reads is not polymorphic. In Java, fields don’t override each other. When you declare className again in Derived, you aren’t replacing the parent’s field, you’re creating a second, unrelated one that happens to have the same name.

getClassName() lives in Base, so the name className inside that method always refers to the Base field. Even when you create a Derived object, the inherited method still uses the field that belongs to the class where the method was originally written.

Here’s a simplified view of what your classes actually look like in memory:

class Base {
    public String className = "Base";   // Base.className

    public String getClassName() {
        return className;              // always Base.className here
    }
}

class Derived extends Base {
    public String className = "Derived"; // Derived.className (a new field)
}

public class Test {
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        Derived d = new Derived();

        System.out.println(d.className);        // prints "Derived"
        System.out.println(((Base)d).className); // prints "Base"
        System.out.println(d.getClassName());    // uses Base.className → "Base"
    }
}

Because fields don’t override, the inherited getClassName() continues to return the parent field.

If you want the value to change in subclasses, either override the method:

class Derived extends Base {
    @Override
    public String getClassName() {
        return "Derived";
    }
}

Or keep a single field and update it from the child:

class Base {
    protected String className = "Base";
    public String getClassName() { return className; }
}

class Derived extends Base {
    public Derived() {
        className = "Derived";
    }
}

This preserves polymorphism and avoids hiding fields.

You need to override the Getter or much better reassign the same field name. Think about it: there should only be one field named "className" only the value should be different when inheriting. It makes sense.

• Hiding Fields in Java Inheritance
  • Getting around field shadowing
  • Field shadowing or overriding?
  • How to shadow a field used in a parent method from a child?
  • Why does the code given below prints value of instance variable of parent class instead of that of child class?
  • Accessing overridden values in child class
  • Access hidden field from subclass of class that hides it
  • java field usage in same assignment as shadowed name

sidenote: you can always call this.getClass().getSimpleName() to get the class name of the actual instance

So it seems the word inherited doesn't have the same sense as in real world.

Absolutely right.

In the real world children are not subtypes of their parents. And a child only inherits from a parent when the parent dies!

Hint: don't try to understand IT concepts by analogy with the real world.
